model#

class Crowding.model.CrowdingEstimator(mu=None, cov_func=<class 'Crowding.cov.Matern52'>, ls=None, nn_distances=None, initial_value=None, L=None, landmarks=5000, rank=0.999, jitter=1e-06, sigma2=1e-06)#

Bases: object

A non-parametric density estimator. CrowdingEstimator performs Bayesian inference, with a Gaussian process prior and Nearest Neighbors likelihood.

Parameters:

  • mu (float) – Mean of the Gaussian process

  • cov_func (function or type) – Gaussian process covariance function. Supports a two argument function or callable k(x, y) \(\rightarrow\) float or a one argument function or class type that takes a length scale argument and returns a function or callable k(x, y) \(\rightarrow\) float. See usage. Defaults to the type Matern52.

  • ls (float) – Length scale of the Gaussian process covariance function. If None, automatically selects the length scale based on the nearest neighbor distances. If cov_func is a function with two arguments, ls is ignored. Defaults to None.

  • nn_distances (array-like or None) – Precomputed nearest neighbor distances at each data point. If None, computes the nearest neighbor distances automatically, with a KDTree if the dimensionality of the data is less than 20, or a BallTree otherwise. Defaults to None.

  • initial_value (array-like or None) – Initial guess for Maximum A Posteriori optimization. If None, finds \(z\) that minimizes \(||Lz + mu - mle|| + ||z||\), where \(mle = \log(\text{gamma}(d/2 + 1)) - (d/2) \cdot \log(\pi) - d \cdot \log(nn\text{_}distances)\), where \(d\) is the dimensionality of the data.

  • L (array-like) – A matrix such that \(L L^T \approx K\), where \(K\) is the covariance matrix.

  • landmarks (array-like or int) – Points to quantize the data for the approximate covariance matrix. If landmarks is an int, landmark points are selected as k-means centroids with k=landmarks. Defaults to the minimum between 5000 and the number of training instances.

  • rank (int or float) – The rank of the covariance matrix. If rank is equal to the number of datapoints, the covariance matrix is exact and full rank. If rank is equal to the number of landmark points, the standard Nystrom approximation is used. If rank is a float greater than 0 and less than 1, the rank is reduced further using the QR decomposition such that the eigenvalues of the included eigenvectors account for the specified percentage of the total eigenvalues. Defaults to 0.999.

  • jitter (float) – A small amount to add to the diagonal of the covariance matrix for numerical stabilitity. Defaults to 1e-6.

  • sigma2 (float) – White noise variance for the case the rank is reduced further than the number of landmark points. Ignored in other cases. Must be greater than 0. Defaults to 1e-6.

Variables:

  • mu – Gaussian process mean.

  • cov_func – Gaussian process covariance function.

  • ls – Gaussian process covariance function length scale.

  • nn_distances – Nearest neighbor distances for each data point.

  • landmark_points – Points to compactly summarize the data.

  • n_landmarks – Number of landmark points.

  • rank – Rank of approximate covariance matrix or percentage of eigenvalues included in approximate covariance matrix.

  • jitter – A small amount added to the diagonal of the covariance matrix for numerical stability.

  • sigma2 – White noise variance for the case the rank is reduced further than the number of landmark points.

  • initial_value – Initial guess for Maximum A Posteriori optimization.

  • L – A matrix such that \(L L^T \approx K\), where \(K\) is the covariance matrix.

  • optimize_result – All results from the optimization.

  • pre_transformation – \(z \sim \text{Normal}(0, I)\) before transformation to Normal:math:(mu, K’), where \(I\) is the identity matrix and \(K'\) is the approximate covariance matrix.

  • loss – Bayesian loss.

  • log_density_x – Log density at the training points.

  • log_density_func – Computes the log density at arbitrary prediction points.

fit(x)#

Perform Bayesian Inference.

Parameters:

x (array-like) – Training instances to estimate density function.

Returns:

self - A fitted instance of this estimator.

Return type:

Object

fit_predict(x)#

Perform Bayesian Inference and return the log density at training points.

Parameters:

x (array-like) – Training instances to estimate density function.

Returns:

log_density_x - The log density at each training point in x.

predict(x)#

Predict the log density at each point in x. Note that in the case that the rank is reduced below the number of landmark points, predictions at the original training points may differ slightly from fit_predict due to the sigma2 noise.

Parameters:

x (array-like) – New data to predict.

Returns:

log_density - The log density at each test point in x.

Return type:

array-like
